column6: M.D.Brandon was a 12-year-old boy brought in by his mother for psychiatric evaluation for temper tantrums that seemed to be contributing to declining school performance. The mother became emotional as she reported that things had always been difficult but had become worse after Brandon entered middle school. Shortly after starting middle school
column7: Brandon had started complaining of stomachaches on school-day mornings and was often reluctant to go to school.Brandon's sixth-grade teachers reported that he was academically capable but that he had little ability to make friends. He seemed to mistrust the intentions of classmates who tried to be nice to him but attempted to befriend others who laughingly feigned interest in the toy cars and trucks that he brought to school. The teachers noted that he often cried and rarely spoke in class. In recent months
column8: multiple teachers had heard him screaming at other boys
column9: generally in the hallway but sometimes in the middle of class.The teachers had not identified a cause but generally had not disciplined Brandon because they assumed he was responding to provocation. He was embarrassed about these outbursts and did not want to go to swim practice because he did not want his swim friends to ask why he'd had an outburst at school.When interviewed alone
column10: Brandon responded with nonspontaneous mumbles when asked questions about school
column11: classmates
column12: and his family. When the examiner asked if he was interested in toy cars
column13: however
column14: Brandon lit up. He pulled several cars
column15: trucks
column16: and airplanes from his backpack and
column17: while not making good eye contact
column18: did talk at length about vehicles
column19: using their apparently accurate names (e.g.
column20: front-end loader
column22: Jaguar). When asked again about school
column23: Brandon pulled out his cell phone and showed a string of text messages: "dumbo!!!!" "mr stutter"; "LoSeR"; "freak!"; "EVERYBODYHATES YOU." While the examiner read the long string of texts that Brandon had saved but apparently not previously revealed
column24: Brandon added that other boys would whisper "bad words" to him in class and then scream in his ears in the hall. "And I hate loud noises." He also told the examiner that he sometimes wished that he had never been born.Developmentally
column25: Brandon spoke his first word at age 11 months and began to use short sentences by age 3. He had always been very focused on trucks
column26: cars
column27: and trains.According to his mother
column28: he had always been "very shy" and had never had a best friend. As he has gotten older
column29: it has become more apparent that he struggles with jokes and typical young adolescent banter because "he takes things so literally." Brandon's mother had long seen this behavior as "a little odd" but added that it was not much different from that of Brandon's father
column30: a successful attorney
column31: who had similarly focused interests. Both of them were "sticklers for routine" who "lacked a sense of humor." Brandon's mother noted that he made efforts to conceal his interest in trucks
column32: cars
column33: and trains outside of the home but would eagerly speak about them when encouraged. Brandon has shared with his mother that he tries to appear "normal" when interacting with peers at school
column34: which is exhausting. He often feels nervous around peers and generally tries to avoid socializing.On examination
column35: Brandon was shy and generally nonspontaneous. He made below- average eye contact. His speech was coherent and goal directed. At times
column36: Brandon stumbled over his words
column37: paused excessively
column38: and sometimes rapidly repeated words or parts of words. Brandon said he felt okay but added that he was scared of school
column39: particularly when around other children. He appeared sad
column40: brightening only when discussing his toy cars. He denied current suicidal thoughts or plans as well as homicidality. He denied psychotic symptoms. He was cognitively intact.§The ICD-11 does not provide a diagnosis for this case. The symptoms described are more aligned with Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) or Autism Spectrum Disorder
column41: characterized by difficulties in social interaction and communication
column42: fixation on specific interests such as toy vehicles
column43: challenges with humor understanding
column44: repetitive behaviors like stuttering
column45: anxiety about school
column46: and potential sensory processing issues. A comprehensive assessment considering these symptoms is required for an accurate diagnosis.(Note: The provided context regarding Disinhibition in dementia (6D86.5) and Wandering in dementia (6D86.6) are not relevant to Brandon's case
column47: as there are no indicators of cognitive disturbances or wandering behavior typical for dementia.)

column1: 2§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Stewart Adelson
column3: Ph.D.Carlos was a 19-year-old Hispanic college student in his freshman year at a public university in a large city. He was referred by his guidance counselor to the hospital's outpatient psychiatric clinic for help with academic difficulties. Since starting college 6 months earlier
column4: he had done poorly on tests and been unable to manage his study schedule. His worries that he was going to flunk out of college were leading to anxiety
column5: insomnia
column6: poor concentration
column7: and a general sense of hopelessness. After a particularly tough week
column8: he told his family that he thought he should quit. His mother accompanied him to the clinic that had previously helped both Carlos and his younger brother. The mother specifically wondered whether Carlos's "ADHD" might be causing his problems
column9: or whether he had outgrown it.Carlos had been seen at the same clinic when he was age 9
column10: at which time he had been diagnosed with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD)
column11: predominantlycombined type. Notes from that clinical evaluation indicated that Carlos had been in trouble at school for not following instructions
column12: not completing homework
column13: getting out of his seat
column14: losing things
column15: not waiting his turn
column16: and not listening. He had trouble concentrating except in regard to video games
column17: which he "could play for hours." Carlos had apparently been slow to talk
column18: but his birth and developmental histories were otherwise normal. He repeated first grade because of behavioral immaturity and difficulty learning to read. The ease with which Carlos learned English
column19: his second language
column20: was not noted. His family had emigrated to the United States from the Dominican Republic when he was 5 years old. The family was Catholic and attended church every Sunday. Both of his parents worked in maintenance and housekeeping at a local municipal hospital.During the evaluation when Carlos was age 9
column21: a psychoeducational assessment by a clinical psychologist confirmed reading problems (particularly problems in reading fluency and comprehension). Carlos did not
column22: however
column23: meet the school board criteria for a learning disability
column24: which required evidence of a 20-point discrepancy between IQ and achievement scores. Thus
column25: he was not eligible for special education services. The evaluator had noted Carlos to be eager to do well and anxious about underperforming.His anxiety was thought to be a reaction to his school difficulties and his challenges in meeting the academic expectations of his family. Carlos's pediatrician had recommended pharmacotherapy
column26: but his parents did not want to pursue medication. They cited negative experiences with local youth who used diverted controlled substances and hung out "on the street." Instead
column27: his mother reported taking on an extra job to pay for tutors to help her son "with concentration and reading." The eldest of four siblings
column28: Carlos had done well with this intervention and was now the first member of his family to attend college.The psychiatry trainee carefully reviewed Carlos's academic history; his symptoms
column29: including the course and severity of sadness
column30: anxiety
column31: insomnia
column32: and hopelessness; and his social and developmental history. She obtained collateral history from his family and school records. She used the revised DSM-5-TR Core Cultural Formulation Interview for assistance in obtaining a better understanding of Carlos's acculturation experiences
column33: the family's past feelings about the clinic's recommendations
column34: and what treatment interventions would be relevant and acceptable to Carlos and his family.The psychiatry trainee learned that Carlos had a childhood history of "nervousness" identified by a neighborhood curandera (traditional healer) as ataque de nervios. The family had addressed this problem with supportive prayer and a traditional herbal tea. They had apparently not revealed this to the psychiatrist at the time
column35: thinking he would find it irrelevant and not wishing to seem disrespectful of his authority. During these unrevealed episodes of acute anxiety
column36: Carlos would experience trembling and agitation
column37: palpitations
column38: shortness of breath
column39: dread of harm
column40: and fear of separation from caregivers. Workup by the pediatrician had revealed no physiological cause.Since starting college
column41: Carlos reported that he had frequently been unable to remain focused while reading and listening to lectures. He was easily sidetracked and therefore had difficulty handing in his written assignments on time. He complained of feeling restless
column42: agitated
column43: and worried. He described difficulty falling asleep
column44: poor energy
column45: and an inability to "have fun" like his peers. He reported that the depressive symptoms went "up and down" over the course of the week and possibly influenced his problems with concentration; it was hard for him to be certain. He denied substance use.Carlos said that he'd had some great teachers in high school who had understood him
column46: helped him get the meaning of what he read
column47: and allowed him to audiotape lectures and use other formats (e.g.
column48: videos
column49: wikis
column50: visual presentations) for final assignments.Without this support at college
column53: a failure-unable to cope."Although advised by his high school teacher to do so
column54: Carlos had not registered with the university's student disability services office. He preferred not to be seen as different from his peers and thought he should be able to get through college by himself.Carlos's family history was positive for ADHD in a younger brother. A cousin was reported to have had "dyslexia" and had dropped out of a local community college after one semester. His social and developmental history revealed that he had been well liked by his cluster of friends throughout school. His group consisted of boys and girls and tended to consist of kids more interested in school than in sports. Carlos denied ever having dated or been sexually active
column55: and he also denied having any significant interest in pursuing either of these activities.On examination
column58: and soft-spoken. He wore clean jeans
column60: and a hoodie that he kept pulling down over his face. He sat quietly and hunched over. He sighed a lot and rarely made eye contact with the clinician. He often tapped his fingers and shuffled in his seat but responded appropriately to questions. His command of English appeared strong
column61: but he spoke with a slight Spanish accent. He often mumbled and mispronounced some multisyllabic words (e.g.
column62: he said "literalchure" instead of "literature" and "intimate" when he clearly meant "intimidate"). He denied any suicidal thoughts. He appeared motivated to do better. On a follow-up interview with the psychiatry trainee
column63: Carlos asked whether the conversations were confidential. When informed that they were
column64: he hesitantly admitted that he felt overwhelmed by new relationships with college peers. He indicated that "in my neighborhood growing up
column67: I'm the only Dominican." He also quietly said that he thought he might "like guys rather than girls." He revealed two recent episodes of panic "like when I was a kid" that had occurred during social situations. He declined to go into further detail.After these two initial sessions
column68: the psychiatrist suggested extending the evaluation so that they could optimize a treatment strategy. She told Carlos that she wanted to better understand his mood and anxiety symptoms
column69: as well as how he felt about being the first in his family to go to college (i.e.
column71: and to talk a little more about his concerns about his sexual orientation. She also referred Carlos for updated psychoeducational testing. This psychoeducational reassessment confirmed that Carlos's reading and writing abilities were substantially and quantifiably below those expected for his age. That report also concluded that these learning difficulties were not attributable to intellectual developmental disorder
column74: or lack of proficiency in the language of academic instruction. The report concluded that Carlos had specific difficulties with reading fluency and comprehension as well as spelling and written expression.§Carlos is exhibiting symptoms that align with Disinhibition (Code: 6D86.5) as outlined under "Disinhibition in dementia." This diagnosis code corresponds to the disorder name and its associated key clinical features described here
column75: where an individual displays a significant lack of restraint alongside impulsivity and poor risk assessment beyond typical cognitive disturbances seen with dementia. Carlos's occasional loss of control in social situations could be indicative of these symptoms—his wandering away from his home at times suggests he may not always adhere to expected boundaries or conventional behavior
column76: placing himself potentially at harm due to this disinhibition and risk-taking tendencies associated with dementia.

column1: 3§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Arden D. Dingle
column4: was brought for a psychiatric evaluation because of academic and behavioral struggles. She had particular difficulty starting and completing schoolwork and following instructions
column5: and she had received failing grades in math. When prompted to complete tasks
column6: Daphne became argumentative and irritable.She had become increasingly resistant to attending school
column7: asking to stay home with her mother. These difficulties had been evident since early childhood but had worsened significantly this year. Because Daphne had become increasingly distressed
column8: her parents have been less insistent on making her do any activity that upsets her.Psychological testing indicated that Daphne had above-average intelligence
column9: age- appropriate achievement in all subjects except math
column10: and some difficulties in visuospatial skills. The test results were shared with the school
column11: which offered additional tutoring. Daphne attended only a few sessions
column12: stating that they were not helpful. Her parents talked to the school counselors and Daphne's teachers
column13: asking for more services. They were told repeatedly that Daphne needed to be more assertive and ask for help.Several teachers commented that Daphne should be more motivated and try harder. Several years earlier
column14: her pediatrician had diagnosed ADHD and prescribed a stimulant.She took the medication for a week
column15: but her parents stopped giving it to her because she seemed agitated.At home
column16: Daphne's parents' close supervision of her homework often led to arguments with crying and screaming. Her behavior and attitude were noticeably better when she was out of school. She had two long-standing friends but had made no new close friends for several years. In groups with other children
column17: she preferred to play with those younger than she. When her friends chose the activity or did not follow her rules
column18: she tended to withdraw. She was generally quiet in groups and in school but more interactive with family members and individuals she knew well.Since early childhood
column19: Daphne has had difficulty falling asleep
column20: requiring a nightlight and parental reassurance. Recognizing that Daphne was easily upset by change
column21: her parents rarely forced her into new activities. She did well during the summer
column22: which she spent with her grandparents. Her parents reported no particular traumas
column23: stressors
column24: or developmental or medical problems. Daphne had started her menses about 2 months prior to the evaluation. Her family history was pertinent for multiple first- and second- degree relatives with mood
column25: anxiety
column26: or learning disorders.At first meeting
column27: Daphne was shy and tense. Her eye contact was poor
column28: and she had difficulty talking about anything other than her plastic horse collection. Within 15 minutes
column29: she became more comfortable
column30: revealing that she disliked school because the work was too hard. She thought that other children did not seem to like her because she was stupid and was not into clothes and dating. Sometimes they made fun of her and would start laughing whenever the teacher called on her. There were several peers who had similar interests in animals and seemed okay. She has been eating lunch with them but found it hard to relax and to believe that they really wanted to be friends. Daphne was always afraid of making mistakes
column31: getting bad grades
column32: and disappointing everyone. Often
column33: she was so preoccupied with what to say or do next that she did not pay attention to her peers or teachers. She frequently was unable to make a decision for fear of not being right. Daphne was unable to identify any personal strengths or any aspect of her life that was going well. She wished she had more friends and that she was smarter. As long as she could remember
column34: she had always felt this way. These difficulties made her sad
column35: but she denied persistent depressive feelings or suicidal thoughts. She appearedanxious but brightened when discussing her horse figurine collection
column36: her longtime friends
column37: and her family.§The ICD-11 diagnosis for Daphne's condition could potentially be Disinhibition in dementia (6D86.5)
column38: given her difficulties with social conventions
column39: impulsivity
column40: and poor decision making which impact daily functioning like school attendance despite a love for animals and interactions at home. However
column41: there is no direct evidence of cognitive decline or wandering behavior typical to dementia in the provided context; thus
column42: this diagnosis might not be fully applicable without further assessment specifically targeted towards neurodegenerative processes.

column1: 4§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Robert Haskell
column4: a 9-year-old boy
column5: was referred to a psychiatric clinic by his teacher
column6: who noticed that his attention was flagging. At that time
column7: Ethan was a fourth grader at a private regular-education school for boys. The teacher told Ethan's parents that although Ethan had been among the best students in his class in the fall
column8: his grades had slipped during the spring semester. He tended to get fidgety and distracted when the academic work became more challenging
column9: and the teacher suggested the parents seek neuropsychiatric testing for him.At home
column10: Ethan's mother explained
column11: he seemed more emotional of late: "He just looks weepy sometimes
column12: which is unusual for him." She denied any difficulties at home
column13: and she described her husband
column14: son
column15: 8-year-old daughter
column16: and herself as a "happy family." She had noticed
column17: however
column18: that Ethan seemed uneasy about being left alone. He hadbecome "clingy
column19: often following his parents around the house, and he hated being in any room by himself. Ethan had also started climbing into bed with his parents in the middle of the night, something he had never done in the past. Although Ethan had a few good friends in the neighborhood and at school and was glad to have other kids come to his house, he refused to go on sleepovers.Ethan's mother agreed that he appeared more fidgety. She had noticed that he often seemed to be shrugging his shoulders, grimacing, and blinking, which she took to be a sign of anxiety. These movements worsened when he was tired or frustrated, and they diminished in frequency during calm, focused activities such as clarinet practice or homework, especially when she was helping him.His mother also mentioned that Ethan had suddenly become superstitious." Whenever he stepped through a doorway
column20: he would go back and forth until he touched both doorjambs with his hands simultaneously
column21: twice in rapid succession. She hoped that Ethan's more conspicuous habits would subside by summer
column22: when the family took its annual vacation. She felt that it was the right year for Disneyland
column23: but Ethan's father had suggested taking him on a fishing trip ("just the boys") while mother and daughter visited relatives in New York City.Ethan's mother recalled her son as an "easy child
column24: but sensitive." He was the product of a planned
column25: uncomplicated pregnancy and met all his developmental milestones on time.He had no history of medical problems or recent infections
column26: but his mother mentioned that he had begun to make frequent visits to the school nurse's office complaining of stomachaches.On examination
column27: Ethan was a slightly built boy with fair
column28: freckly skin and blond hair. He was somewhat fidgety
column29: tugging at his pants and shifting in his seat. Hearing his mother talk about his new movements seemed to provoke them
column30: and the examiner noted that Ethan also occasionally blinked tightly
column31: rolled his eyes
column32: and made throat-clearing noises. Ethan said that he sometimes worried about "bad things" happening to his parents. His concerns were vague
column33: however
column34: and he seemed to fear only that burglars might break into their house.§Based on ICD-11 context provided
column35: Ethan's symptoms may align with Disinhibition in dementia (6D86.5)
column36: which includes disregard for social conventions
column37: impulsivity
column38: and poor risk assessment. However
column39: there is not enough information about cognitive disturbances directly related to a diagnosis of dementia. Ethan's wandering behavior could potentially be part of the broader symptomatology if it places him at risk or relates to significant disinhibition behaviors like following parents around and seeking physical closeness (6D86.6). Further evaluation is necessary for a definitive diagnosis.

column1: 5§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Carol A. Tamminga
column2: M.D.Felicia Allen was a 32-year-old single woman brought to the emergency room (ER) by police after she apparently tried to steal a city bus in Chicago. Because she appeared tobe an "emotionally disturbed person
column3: a psychiatry consultation was requested.According to the police report, Ms. Allen threatened the driver with a knife, took control of the almost empty city bus, and crashed it. A more complete story was elicited from a friend of Ms. Allen's who had been on the bus but who had not been arrested. According to her, they had boarded the bus on their way to a nearby shopping mall. Ms. Allen became frustrated when the driver refused her dollar bills, instead demanding exact change. She looked in her purse, but instead of finding exact change, she pulled out a kitchen knife that she carried for protection. The driver fled, so she got into the empty seat and drove the bus across the street into a nearby parked car.On examination, Ms. Allen was a handcuffed, heavyset young woman with a bandage on her forehead. She fidgeted and rocked back and forth in her chair. She appeared to be mumbling to herself. When asked what she was saying, the patient made momentary eye contact and just repeated, Sorry
column4: sorry." She did not respond to other questions.More information was elicited from a psychiatrist who had come to the ER soon after the accident. He said that Ms. Allen and her friend were longtime residents at the state psychiatric hospital where he worked. They had just begun to take passes every week as part of an effort toward social remediation; it had been Ms. Allen's first bus ride without a staff member.According to the psychiatrist
column5: Ms. Allen had received a diagnosis of "childhood-onset
column6: treatment-resistant paranoid schizophrenia." She had started hearing voices by age 5 years. Big
column7: strong
column8: intrusive
column9: and psychotic
column10: she had been hospitalized almost constantly since age 11. Her auditory hallucinations generally consisted of a critical voice commenting on her behavior. Her thinking was concrete
column11: but when relaxed she could be self-reflective. She was motivated to please and recurrently said her biggest goal was to "have my own room in my own house with my own friends." The psychiatrist said that he was not sure what had caused her to pull out the knife. She had not been hallucinating lately and had been feeling less paranoid
column12: but he wondered if she had been more psychotic than she had let on. It was possible that she was just impatient and irritated.The psychiatrist also believed that she had spent almost no period of life developing normally and so had very little experience with the real world.Ms. Allen had been taking clozapine for 1 year
column13: with good resolution of her auditory hallucinations. She had gained 35 pounds on the clozapine
column14: but she had less trouble getting out of bed in the morning and was functioning at a higher level. She was hoping to get a job and live more independently
column15: and the bus trip had been intended as a step in that direction. Because of these improvements and goals
column16: she had insisted on continuing to take the clozapine despite the weight gain.§Carol A. Tamminga's patient exhibits symptoms consistent with paranoid schizophrenia (ICD-11 code not provided)
column17: characterized by auditory hallucinations
column18: concrete thinking
column19: social withdrawal
column20: and possible impulsivity leading to unsafe behaviors like attempting to steer a bus. The history of hospitalizations since childhood due to severe psychosis aligns with this diagnosis rather than an eating disorder or dementia-related wandering/disinhibition as these conditions present differently in terms of cognitive symptoms and daily functioning which are not described here for the patient Felicia Allen.

column1: 6§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: William S. Stone
column4: Ph.D.
column5: D.Sc.Gregory Baker was a 20-year-old African American man who was brought to the emergency room (ER) by the campus police of the university from which he had been suspended several months earlier. The police had been called by a professor who reported that Mr. Baker had walked into his classroom shouting
column6: "I am the Joker
column7: and I am looking for Batman." When Mr. Baker refused to leave the class
column8: the professor contacted security.Although Mr. Baker had much academic success as a teenager
column9: his behavior had become increasingly odd during the past year. He quit seeing his friends and spent most of his time lying in bed staring at the ceiling. He lived with several family members but rarely spoke to any of them. He had been suspended from college because of lack of attendance. His sister said that she had recurrently seen him mumbling quietly to himself and noted that he would sometimes
column10: at night
column11: stand on the roof of their home and wave his arms as if he were "conducting a symphony." He denied having anyintention of jumping from the roof or having any thoughts of self-harm
column12: but claimed that he felt liberated and in tune with the music when he was on the roof. Although his father and sister had tried to encourage him to see someone at the university's student health clinic
column13: Mr. Baker had never seen a psychiatrist and had no prior hospitalizations.During the prior several months
column14: Mr. Baker had become increasingly preoccupied with a female friend
column15: Anne
column16: who lived down the street. While he insisted to his family that they were engaged
column17: Anne told Mr. Baker's sister that they had hardly ever spoken and certainly were not dating. Mr. Baker's sister also reported that he had written many letters to Anne but never mailed them; instead
column18: they just accumulated on his desk.His family said that they had never known him to use illicit substances or alcohol
column19: and his toxicology screen was negative. When asked about drug use
column20: Mr. Baker appeared angry and did not answer.On examination in the ER
column21: Mr. Baker was a well-groomed young man who was generally uncooperative. He appeared constricted
column22: guarded
column23: inattentive
column24: and preoccupied. He became enraged when the ER staff brought him dinner. He loudly insisted that all of the hospital's food was poisoned and that he would only drink a specific type of bottled water. He was noted to have paranoid
column25: grandiose
column26: and romantic delusions. He appeared to be internally preoccupied
column27: although he denied hallucinations. Mr. Baker reported feeling "bad" but denied depression and did not show disturbances in his sleep or appetite. He was adequately oriented to person and place but less so to time. He spoke articulately but refused formal cognitive testing. His insight and judgment were deemed to be poor.Mr. Baker's grandmother had died in a state psychiatric hospital
column28: where she had lived for 30 years. Her diagnosis was unknown. Mr. Baker's mother was reportedly "crazy." She had abandoned the family when Mr. Baker was young
column29: and he was raised by his father and paternal grandmother.Ultimately
column30: Mr. Baker agreed to sign himself into the psychiatric unit
column31: stating
column32: "I don't mind staying here. Anne will probably be there
column33: so I can spend my time with her."§Based on ICD-11 criteria
column34: Mr. Baker could be diagnosed with Delusional Disorder
column35: specifically subtype 'in full remission' (6A24.2) as he previously exhibited symptoms such as grandiose and romantic delusions without significant presence of these at the current time. However
column36: his insight into this condition appears to still be poorly developed.

column1: 7§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Lianne K. Morris Smith
column4: M.P.H.Hakim Coleman was a 25-year-old U.S. Army veteran turned community college student who presented to the emergency room (ER) with his girlfriend and sister. Onexamination
column5: he was a tall
column6: slim
column7: and well-groomed young man with glasses. He spoke softly
column8: with an increased latency of speech. His affect was blunted except when he became anxious while discussing his symptoms.Mr. Coleman stated that he had come to the ER at his sister's suggestion. He said he could use a "general checkup" because of several days of "migraines" and "hallucinations of a spiritual nature" that had persisted for 3 months. His headache involved "sharp
column9: shooting" sensations in various bilateral locations in his head and a "ringing" sensation along the midline of his brain that seemed to worsen when he thought about his vices.Mr. Coleman described his vices as being "alcohol
column10: cigarettes
column11: disrespecting my parents
column12: girls." He denied guilt
column13: anxiety
column14: or preoccupation with any of his military duties during his tour in Iraq
column15: although his sister shared that Hakim's military responsibilities were of a confidential nature. He had joined an evangelical church 4 months earlier in the context of being "riddled with guilt" about "all the things I've done." Three months earlier
column16: he began "hearing voices trying to make me feel guilty" most days. The last auditory hallucination had been the day before. During these past few months
column17: he became withdrawn and noticed that strangers were commenting on his past sins.Mr. Coleman believed that his migraines and guilt might be due to alcohol withdrawal. He had been drinking three or four cans of beer most days of the week for several years until he "quit" 4 months earlier after joining the church. He still drank "a beer or two" every other week but felt guilty afterward. He denied alcohol withdrawal symptoms such as tremor and sweats. He had smoked cannabis up to twice monthly for years but completely quit when he joined the church. He denied using other illicit drugs except for one uneventful use of cocaine 3 years earlier. He sometimes would sleep only a few hours and did report some nightmares. Otherwise
column18: Mr. Coleman denied depressive
column19: manic
column20: or psychotic symptoms and violent ideation.Regarding PTSD
column21: Mr. Coleman's score on the 20-item self-administered PTSD Checklist for DSM-5 was below the cutoff score (between 31 and 33 out of 80) that would indicate probable PTSD in veterans. He denied that his military experience was unusually or especially frightening
column22: horrible
column23: or traumatic. Regarding other stressors
column24: he felt overwhelmed by his current responsibilities
column25: which included attending school and near-daily church activities. He had been a straight-A student at the start of the school year but was now receiving Bs and Cs.The patient's girlfriend and sister were interviewed separately. They agreed that Mr. Coleman had become socially isolative and quiet
column26: after having previously been fun and outgoing. He had also never been especially religious prior to this episode. His sister believed that Mr. Coleman had been "brainwashed" by the church. His girlfriend
column27: however
column28: had attended services with Mr. Coleman. She reported that several members of the congregation had told her they had occasionally talked to new members who felt guilt over their prior behaviors
column29: but none who had ever hallucinated
column30: and they were worried about him.A physical examination of the patient
column31: including a neurological screen
column32: was unremarkable
column33: as were routine laboratory testing
column34: a blood alcohol level
column35: and urine toxicology. A noncontrast head computed tomography (CT) scan was normal.§The diagnosis for Hakim Coleman could be Substance/Medication-Induced Disorder due to Alcohol Intoxication (F10.26) and Hallucinogen Persisting Perception Disorder (R44.8). The hallucinations
column36: along with his behavioral changes after quitting alcohol use
column37: suggest substance-related issues rather than primary psychiatric disorders like those listed under dementia codes 6D86.5 and 6D86.6 which involve cognitive disturbances characteristic of a neurodegenerative process leading to wandering or impulsivity without the presence of hallucinations as described in this case.

column1: 8§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Rajiv Tandon
column2: M.D.Itsuki Daishi was a 23-year-old engineering student from Japan who was referred to his university student mental health clinic by a professor who had become concerned about his irregular class attendance. When they had met to discuss his declining performance
column3: Mr. Daishi had volunteered to the professor that he was distracted by the "listening devices" and "thought control machines" that had been placed in his apartment.While initially wary of talking to the psychiatrist
column4: Mr. Daishi indicated that he was relieved to finally get a chance to talk in a room that had not yet been bugged. He said that his problems began 3 months earlier
column5: after he returned from a visit to Japan. He said his first indication of trouble was when a classmate sneezed and grinned at him in an odd way. Later that same week
column6: he noticed two strangers lurking suspiciously outside his apartment.Mr. Daishi decided that those lurking strangers had installed tiny mind-control devices throughout his apartment
column7: devices that were intended to weaken his resolve and prepare him for an onslaught of misinformation from Fox News reporters who intended to convert him into being a follower of Donald Trump. After weakening his resolve
column8: Mr.Daishi found himself only able to watch Fox News
column9: and he then found that those television reporters began to relentlessly comment indirectly and critically about him. He soon came to the conclusion that they had targeted him because of his "superior intelligence" and because he would soon become the prime minister of Japan. He concluded that the Trump Republicans wanted an ally in Tokyo. Mr. Daishi indicated that he was trying to stay strong
column10: but it was difficult to keep the reporters from putting ideas into his head.Mr. Daishi reported that he became increasingly vigilant
column11: fearing that everyone at school and in his apartment complex was "in on the plot." He slept little
column12: became withdrawn
column13: and stopped attending classes
column14: but he did continue to eat and maintain his personal hygiene.He denied feeling elated or euphoric. He described his level of energy as "okay" and histhinking as clear "except when they try to put ideas into my head." He admitted to feeling extremely fearful for several hours on one occasion during his recent trip to Japan. At that time
column15: he had smoked "a lot of pot" and began hearing strange sounds and believing that his friends were laughing at him. He denied any cannabis consumption since his return to the United States and denied ever having experimented with any other substances
column16: saying that he generally would not even drink alcohol. He denied all other history of auditory or visual hallucinations.When Mr. Daishi's uncle
column17: listed as his local guardian
column18: was contacted
column19: he described his nephew as a healthy
column20: intelligent
column21: and somewhat shy boy without any prior history of any major psychiatric illness. He described Mr. Daishi's parents as very loving and supportive
column22: although his father "might be a little stern." There was no family history of any major mental illness.On examination
column23: Mr. Daishi was well groomed and cooperative
column24: with normal psychomotor activity. His speech was coherent and goal directed. He described his mood as "afraid." The range and mobility of his affective expression were normal. He denied any ideas of guilt
column25: suicide
column26: or worthlessness. He was convinced that he was being continuously monitored and that there were "mind control" devices in his apartment. He denied hallucinations. His cognitive functions were generally within normal limits. He appeared to have no insight into his beliefs.On investigation
column27: Mr. Daishi's laboratory test results were normal
column28: his head computed tomography scan was unremarkable
column29: and his urine drug screen was negative for any substances of abuse.§The case does not align with ICD-11 criteria for either Disinhibition in Dementia (6D86.5) or Wandering in Dementia (6D86.6)
column30: as Mr. Daishi lacks cognitive impairments typical of dementia and his symptoms do not include disregard for social conventions
column31: impulsivity related to poor risk assessment
column32: nor does he exhibit clinically significant wandering behavior harmful to himself or others. Instead
column33: the case may represent delusional jealousy with paranoid ideation (F22.-)
column34: although this diagnosis requires a thorough evaluation beyond provided context and professional mental health examination for confirmation.

19§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Ian Jones, M.R.C.Psych., Ph.D.Ursula Norman, a 32-year-old nurse, was brought to an emergency department 6 days after giving birth. Her husband stated that she had been behaving very strangely and that she had become convinced that she had smothered and killed her baby.Her husband reported that after a normal pregnancy and uncomplicated delivery, Ms. Norman had happily gone home with their first child. On the third day after delivery, however, her mood and affect began to shift rapidly between elation and weepiness. She became irritable and anxious. She slept only an hour a night, even when her baby was asleep. Her behavior became increasingly bizarre, with overactivity and agitation. Her speech was rapid and digressive. Although not previously a religious person, she became convinced that God was speaking through her and that she had special powers that could solve the problems of the world. She told her husband that she could identify evil people by looking into their eyes and had begun to worry that she was surrounded by evil people, including her own mother. Most disturbing for her, whenever she was out of sight of her son, she became totally convinced that she had smothered him, and no one could convince her otherwise.Ms. Norman had a history of three episodes of major depressive disorder in her teens and early 20s. These episodes resolved with psychotherapy and antidepressant medication. She also had a psychiatric admission for mania 3 years prior to the delivery of her child, after a flight from Asia to Europe. Following treatment with antipsychotic medication, she became depressed for several months. Although a diagnosis of bipolar disorder was discussed at this time, she was reluctant to accept this label, attributing the episode to stress and jet lag. She had discontinued the psychiatric medication in anticipation of getting pregnant.Ms. Norman's own mother had been admitted to a psychiatric hospital shortly after the birth of her first child. This episode was not talked about in the family, and there were few other details. She had no other family history of note.Until just before delivery of her child, Ms. Norman had been a highly functional nurse in a renal unit. Her husband was the head of a sales team, and they lived in comfortable social circumstances. She had no history of illicit drug use and, prior to pregnancy, drank only 2 or 3 units of alcohol a week.On mental status examination, Ms. Norman wandered around the room, seemingly unable to sit for more than a few moments. She was distractible and overtalkative, and demonstrated flight of ideas, flitting from one subject to another. Her mood was labile. At times she appeared happily euphoric. At other times she was tearful, and she could become quickly irritable when she felt she was not being understood. It was clear that she had a number of delusional beliefs but was unwilling to discuss most of them with the examiner. She did insist that she had already killed her own child, which led to several minutes of tears, but she returned to an edgy euphoria within a few minutes. She denied intent to harm herself or anyone else. She appeared inattentive, with poor concentration, but would not participate in formal cognitive testing.Physical examination and laboratory testing results were all within normal limits.§The diagnosis for Ursula Norman may be Wandering in Dementia (ICD-11 code: 6D86.6), characterized by her restlessness and impulsivity, possibly exacerbated postpartum stress combined with a history of bipolar disorder episodes which could relate to cognitive disturbances typically seen in dementia. Her recent behavior aligns closely with wandering tendencies where she is at risk due to these uncharacteristic actions following childbirth.
20§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Holly A. Swartz, M.D.Victoria Owens, a divorced 58-year-old event planner, scheduled an appointment with a psychiatrist for help with anxiety and depression. Ms. Owens arrived at the appointment well dressed and a little agitated. Speaking at a normal pace, she explained that her depressive symptoms had begun 2 years earlier in the setting of initiating divorce proceedings from her fourth husband. She described poor mood, incapacitating worry about her future, and poor concentration. These symptoms progressed to anhedonia, decreased energy, hypersomnia with interrupted sleep, passive suicidal ideation, and increased appetite with carbohydrate craving. She stopped going to work as an event planner and began spending most of the day in bed.Ms. Owens initially sought treatment from a homeopath, who prescribed a variety of remedies that were not helpful. She eventually saw her internist, who prescribed alprazolam 0.25 mg three times a day as needed. This medication reduced her worry but had little effect on her mood. Her internist then initiated sertraline 50 mg/day, increasing the dosage (as tolerated) to 200 mg/day. Over the ensuing 2 months, Ms.Owens's sleep improved and she no longer experienced suicidal thoughts. However, she became more anxious, irritable, agitated, and energized and noted that her thoughts moved rapidly. She denied impulsivity and psychotic symptoms.Ms. Owens had a long-standing history of similar depressive episodes. The first such episode occurred during college, lasted for several months, and was untreated.When specifically asked, she described multiple periods in her life when she had moderately elevated mood, rapid thoughts, and increased energy. It seemed that many important life accomplishments occurred during these periods. For instance, as a young, recently divorced unemployed single mother, she agreed to throw a bridal shower for her best friend. She pored over bridal and craft magazines, determined to create a fabulous party on a shoestring budget. She became totally engrossed in the project, seeming to have abundant energy and ideas. The shower was a huge success and launched Ms.Owens's career as a party planner. She hid her mood swings from her clients and colleagues, leveraging her elevated mood states to project a high-energy face
column49: but then would retreat and avoid work when her mood became low. She also became more irritable during these high-energy episodes, and she believed that each of her marriages both began and ended because of her tendency to get emotional" when she was in these elevated mood states. column55: and her brother was treated with lithium for bipolar disorder.§Based on ICD-11 criteria and provided context

28§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Edward V. Nunes, M.D.Frank Young, a 40-year-old business executive, was brought for a psychiatric consultation by his wife. While Mr. Young sat quietly beside her, she reported that a change had come over him during the last 6 months. He was either quiet and withdrawn or uncharacteristically irritable. He had begun to drink alcohol to excess in social situations, sometimes embarrassing her. He often came home late, or not at all, claiming to have been at the office. When away from home, he rarely answered phone calls and text messages. She wondered if he was having an affair. Mr. Young denied seeing anyone else and indicated he had just been having a hard time.After his wife left the psychiatrist's office, Mr. Young reported a great deal of stress at work over the last year as he tried to deal with industry-wide setbacks and personal financial losses. He said he felt down and depressed most of the time. He reported difficulty sleeping most nights, loss of interest in his wife and children, low energy, and feelings of failure and self-criticism. He had frequent thoughts of wanting to be dead and of suicide, but he denied any suicidal intent or plans.When asked about the alcohol, he acknowledged that he had been drinking heavily for at least 6 months. When asked about other substances, he asked about therapeutic confidentiality and then acknowledged that he had been using cocaine several times per week for about 9 months. He kept his cocaine use from his wife because he knew she would be judgmental. In the beginning, cocaine put him in a reliably positive, optimistic mood, and he found that he could more successfully churn through large volumes of otherwise tedious and discouraging work. Although his work required some socializing in the evening, he also began to regularly go to bars in the evening just so that he would have a place to comfortably combine cocaine with alcohol. He craved the high from cocaine, went out of his way to obtain it, and spent a lot of time getting high that he would previously have been spending with his family.When asked to clarify the sequence of work stress, cocaine use, and depressionsymptoms, he reported that he had felt worried and discouraged about work for a year, but the feelings of depression, loss of interest, irritability, insomnia, and low self-esteem had not begun until about 6 months earlier, 3 months after he had begun to use cocaine regularly. He experienced those depressive symptoms most of the day every day, whether or not he had taken cocaine within the last several days.Mr. Young denied any previous episodes of depression, other mood or anxiety disorders, or suicide attempts. He drank socially. He had experimented with cannabis and cocaine as a teenager but had never developed a pattern of regular use or impairment until the past year.§Delusional Disorder (6A24.0) is most fitting based on ICD-11 criteria given the patient's fixed false belief of infidelity without any evidence, coupled with significant distress or impairment in social functioning due to these delusions. The symptoms have been present for more than one month and do not appear to be a direct result of physiological effects of substances (alcohol/cocaine). Wandering dementia codes are less applicable as the primary issue is psychiatric, rather than cognitive decline with wandering risks. Disinhibition in dementia does not fully capture his lack of restraint due to alcohol and cocaine use or delusional thinking about affairs.(Note: In real practice for accurate diagnosis a comprehensive assessment by a professional is required, which may consider differentials like substance-induced mood disorder.)

column15: anxious" child and "not a troublemaker." Her older brother abused multiple substances
column16: although Ms. Bates said she herself had never used illicit substances. Her older sister was treated for "panic attacks and depression
column17: and Ms. Bates knew of several aunts and cousins whom she thought were depressed."On examination
column18: Ms. Bates was a pleasant
column19: well-related
column20: casually but appropriately dressed
column21: moderately overweight woman
column22: appearing her stated age
column23: who made good eye contact. Her speech was somewhat rapid and verbose but interruptible and nonpressured. She had no abnormal motor movements
column24: but she gestured dramatically and with excessive animation. Her mood was depressed
column25: and her affect was tense and dysphoric but with full range and normal responsivity. Ms. Bates's thought processes were somewhat circumstantial but generally coherent
column26: linear
column27: and logical. Her thought content was notable for passive thoughts that she might be better off dead
column28: but without intent or plan; she had no delusions
column29: hallucinations
column30: or homicidal thoughts. Her higher integrative functioning was grossly intact
column31: as were her insight and judgment.§The ICD-11 criteria suggest a possible diagnosis of Bipolar Type II Disorder (Code: 6A61.A). While Ms. Bates does not currently meet the full syndrome for active bipolar disorder
column32: her history indicates periods consistent with hypomanic or depressive episodes prior to remission and recent behavior aligning with impulsivity and poor risk assessment associated with this condition. However
column33: a definitive diagnosis would require further evaluation of symptomatology over time. (3 sentences)

column1: 31§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Peter D. Kramer
column2: M.D.Ian Campbell was a 32-year-old architect who presented for psychiatric consultation because he was floundering at work. His boss had expressed concern after he failed to make progress on a simple project. When Mr. Campbell explained that he had been distracted by problems at home
column3: his boss suggested that more seemed wrong. Mr.Campbell called his internist
column4: who sent him to a neurologist
column5: who referred him for psychiatric evaluation.Mr. Campbell had encountered this problem
column6: difficulty concentrating
column7: before. In college
column8: after his father died of a chronic illness
column9: Mr. Campbell had been unable to study and had taken time off. Twice at his prior job
column10: he experienced episodes lasting months in which he had difficulty making decisions. One of these intervals followed a romantic setback.The patient's mother and sister had been diagnosed with major depressive disorder and treated successfully with medication. A maternal uncle had committed suicide.The current impairment's onset accompanied the breakdown of Mr. Campbell's marriage of 6 years. Two months earlier
column11: his wife had filed for divorce
column12: announcing that she would live in the distant city her work had taken her to. Mr. Campbell had expected to feel relief; he said his wife had been hostile throughout the marriage. He had begun to entertain fond thoughts of a coworker. Nevertheless
column13: he felt "flat"-unable to imagine a future.Closer questioning revealed that Mr. Campbell's problems went beyond impaired cognition. He described apathy and diminished energy. Jazz was a passion
column14: but he no longer attended recitals-although impaired concentration probably played a role as well. Listening
column15: the psychiatrist noted probable retardation of speech. Mr. Campbell said that his employer had mentioned that he was "moving in slow motion." The problems were worse in the mornings. In the evenings
column16: Mr. Campbell noticed a spark of energy. He put on music and reviewed reports that he had ignored during the workday.Mr. Campbell declined to characterize himself as sad. He was pleased that the marriage was ending. But the psychiatrist was struck by her own affect in Mr. Campbell's presence; she felt glum
column17: pessimistic
column18: even weepy.She questioned Mr. Campbell at length about depressed mood
column19: changed sleep and appetite
column20: feelings of guilt or worthlessness
column21: and thoughts of death. None of these attributions
column22: he said
column23: applied. Nor had he had indicators of disorders that can be confused with depression. Between episodes of impairment
column24: he felt and functioned well.The psychiatrist decided that the problem at hand was close enough to depression to warrant treatment. Factors that influenced her decision included the partial syndromal presentation
column25: diurnal variation
column26: periodic recurrence
column27: lack of future orientation
column28: and her own empathic experience. She proposed psychotherapy centered on Mr. Campbell's decompensation in the face of loss. He insisted that he did not see the impending divorce in that light. The two agreed on brief psychotherapy supplemented by antidepressants.Within weeks
column29: Mr. Campbell was functioning at full capacity. During the treatment
column30: the psychiatrist was unable to elicit evidence of depressive symptoms beyond those noted in the initial history. All the same
column31: she was convinced that the impaired concentration was a sign and symptom of something very much like major depressive disorder.§Based on ICD-11 criteria and context provided
column32: Peter D. Kramer may be experiens with Recurrent depressive disorder in partial remission (6A71.6)
column33: given his history of intermittent episodes affecting concentration along with some residual mood symptoms despite periods without significant impairment.

column1: 32§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Russell F. Lim
column4: was referred to a mental health care clinic after she recurrently complained to her primary care physician of fatigue

column15: her son
column16: his wife

Her son had employed her two daughters on the farm until both had moved back to live in the Hmong community in Sacramento.Ms. Fang indicated that the transition to California had gone better than she had expected. The biggest disappointments for her had been her husband's unexpected death from a heart attack 1 year earlier and the fact that most of her extended family had remained in Thailand.On mental status examination

column22: black flip-flops
column23: and no makeup. She had white strings tied around her wrists. Her eyes were generally downcast

column26: and homicidality. Cognitive testing revealed normal attention and concentration. She had little formal education and appeared to be functionally illiterate. Her insight into her illness appeared limited.When asked about the strings around her wrists

column1: 33§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Loes Jongerden
column3: Ph.D.Logan was a 12-year-old boy who was referred to mental health care for long-standing anxiety about losing his parents and relatively recent fears about getting a severe disease.Although his parents described a long history of anxiety
column4: Logan's acute problem began 5 weeks prior to the consultation
column5: when he watched a television show about rare and fatal diseases. Afterward
column6: he became scared that he might have a hidden disease. His parents reported three "panic attacks" in the prior month
column7: marked by anxiety
column8: dizziness
column9: sweats
column10: and shortness of breath. About that same time
column11: Logan began to complain of frequent headaches and stomachaches. Logan's own theory was that his bodily aches were causedby his fears about being ill and about his parents going away
column12: but the pain was still uncomfortable. He insisted he was not scared about having more panic attacks but was petrified about being left sick and alone. These illness fears developed several times a week
column13: usually when Logan was in bed
column14: when he "felt something" in his body
column15: or when he heard about diseases.Logan had begun to suffer from anxieties as a young child. Kindergarten was notable for intense separation difficulties. He was briefly bullied in third grade
column16: which led to his first panic attacks and worsening anxiety. According to his parents
column17: "there always seemed to be a new anxiety." These included fear of the toilet
column18: the dark
column19: sleeping alone
column20: being alone
column21: and being pestered.Logan's most persistent fear revolved around his parents' safety. He was generally fine when both were at work or at home
column22: but when they were in transit
column23: or anywhere else
column24: he was generally afraid that they would die in an accident. When the parents were late from work or when they tried to go out together or on an errand without him
column25: Logan became frantic
column26: calling and texting incessantly. Logan was predominantly concerned about his mother's safety
column27: and she had gradually reduced her solo activities to a minimum. As she said
column28: it felt like "he would like to follow me into the toilet." Logan was less demanding toward his father
column29: who believed his wife had been too soft and overprotective.Logan and his family underwent several months of psychotherapy when Logan was age10. The father said therapy helped his wife become less overprotective
column30: and Logan's anxiety seemed to improve. Logan's mother agreed with this assessment
column31: although she said she was not sure what she was supposed to do when her son was panicking whenever she tried to leave the house or whenever he worried about getting a disease.Logan's developmental history was otherwise unremarkable. His grades were generally good. His teachers agreed that he was quiet but had several friends and collaborated well with other children. He was quick
column32: however
column33: to negatively interpret the intentions of other children. For example
column34: he tended to be very sensitive to any indication that he was being picked on.Logan's family history was pertinent for panic disorder
column35: agoraphobia
column36: and social anxiety disorder in the mother. The maternal grandmother was described as "at least as" anxiousas Logan's mother. The father denied psychiatric illness in his family.On examination
column37: Logan was a friendly
column38: articulate boy who was cooperative and goal directed. He was generally in a "good mood" but cried when talking about his fears of dying and getting sick. He denied suicidality and hopelessness but indicated he was desperate to get over his problems before starting high school. His cognition was good. His insight and judgment appeared intact except as related to his anxiety issues.§Based on ICD-11 context for disinhibition and lack of restraint in social settings (6D86.5)
column39: Logan may be experiencing a form of behavioral disturbance common to some psychiatric conditions
column40: which overlaps with his anxiety symptoms but does not align precisely as wandering typically involves physical movement outside the home or property leading to potential harm. However
column41: there is no direct indication in this context that he displays these specific ICD-11 behaviors described for dementia patients (6D86.5 and 6D86.6). Logan's case seems more related to anxiety disorders with panic attacks and fear of illness
column42: rather than the symptoms outlined under 'Disinhibition in Dementia'. If he were displaying wandering behavior as described for dementia (6D86.6)
column43: it was not mentioned here. Therefore
column44: his diagnosis may lean towards an anxiety spectrum disorder with elements of panic attacks and separation concerns rather than the ICD-10 codes provided which pertain to cognitive disturbances in dementia patients.(Note: There is no exact match for Logan's case using only given context; thus
column45: this response synthesizes information within the limits while acknowledging that a diagnosis beyond anxiety disorders might be needed.)

column1: 34§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Carlo Faravelli
column2: M.D.Maria Greco was a 23-year-old single woman who was referred for psychiatric evaluation by her cardiologist. In the prior 2 months

column4: shortness of breath
column5: sweats
column6: trembling

column8: leaving her scared
column9: exhausted
column10: and fully convinced that she had just experienced a heart attack. Medical evaluations done right after these episodes yielded normal physical exam findings
column11: vital signs
column12: lab results
column13: toxicology screens
column14: and electrocardiograms.The patient reported a total of five such attacks in the prior 3 months
column15: with the panic occurring at work
column16: at home
column17: and while driving a car. She had developed a persistent fear of having other attacks
column18: which led her to take many days off work and to avoid exercise
column19: driving
column20: and coffee. Her sleep quality declined
column21: as did her mood. She avoided social relationships. She did not accept the reassurance offered to her by friends and physicians
column22: believing that the medical workups were negative because they were performed after the resolution of the symptoms. She continued to suspect that something was wrong with her heart and that without an accurate diagnosis
column23: she was going to die. When she had a panic attack while asleep in the middle of the night
column24: she finally agreed to see a psychiatrist.Ms. Greco denied a history of previous psychiatric disorders except for a history of anxiety during childhood that had been diagnosed as a "school phobia."The patient's mother had committed suicide by overdose 4 years earlier in the context of recurrent major depressive disorder. At the time of the evaluation
column25: the patient was living with her father and two younger siblings. The patient had graduated from high school
column26: was working as a telephone operator
column27: and was not dating anyone. Her family and social histories were otherwise noncontributory.On examination
column28: the patient was an anxious-appearing
column29: cooperative
column30: coherent young woman. She denied depression but did appear worried and was preoccupied with ideas of having heart disease. She denied psychotic symptoms
column31: confusion
column32: and all suicidality. Her cognition was intact
column33: insight was limited
column34: and judgment was fair.§The diagnosis for Maria Greco is Bipolar type II disorder
column35: current episode depressive
column36: moderate with psychotic symptoms. This conclusion comes from her history of recurrent severe panic attacks without physical causes (psychotic symptoms)
column37: significant impact on daily functioning and quality of life
column38: as well as the presence of delusions or hallucinations related to health concerns indicating a depressive episode at moderate severity with psychotic features. The ICD-10 criteria are not directly applicable here since they were asked for in relation to ICD-11 context; however
column39: this diagnosis aligns closely with DSM-5 classifications which correspond more accurately to the provided clinical details and symptomatology of Maria Greco's case.

column1: 35§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Barbara L. Milrod
column2: M.D.Nadine was a 15-year-old girl whose mother brought her for a psychiatric evaluation to help with her long-standing shyness.Although Nadine was initially reluctant to say much about herself
column3: she said she felt constantly tense. She added that the anxiety had been "really bad" for several years and was often accompanied by episodes of dizziness and crying. She was generally unable to speak in any situation outside of her home or school classes. She refused to leave her house alone for fear of being forced to interact with someone. She was especially anxious around other teenagers
column4: but she had also become "too nervous" to speak to adult neighbors she had known for years. She said it felt impossible to walk into a restaurant and order from "a stranger at the counter" for fear of being humiliated. She also felt constantly on her guard
column5: needing to avoid the possibility of getting attacked
column6: a strategy that really only worked when she was alone in her home.Nadine tried to conceal her crippling anxiety from her parents
column7: typically telling them that she "just didn't feel like" going out. Feeling trapped and incompetent
column8: Nadine said she contemplated suicide "all the time." In the month before her mother finally brought her in for a psychiatric evaluation
column9: Nadine had begun to cut herself on her thighs to "feel pain and relieve stress." No one in the family was aware of this development.Nadine had always been "shy" and had been teased at recess since she started kindergarten. The teasing had escalated to outright bullying by the time she was in seventh grade. The bullying took on a cultural/racially motivated undertone; Nadine and her family were of a different ethnicity than the vast majority of her schoolmates. For 2 years
column10: day after difficult day
column11: Nadine's peers turned on her "like a snarling wolf pack
column12: calling her stupid
column13: ugly
column14: and crazy." Not infrequently
column15: one of them would stare at her and tell her she would be better off committing suicide. One girl (the ringleader
column16: as well as a former elementary school chum) hit Nadine on one occasion
column17: giving her a black eye. Nadine did not fight back. This event was witnessed by an adult neighbor
column18: who told Nadine's mother. When Nadine's mother asked her about the incident
column19: Nadine denied it
column20: saying she had "fallen" on the street. She did
column21: however
column22: mention to her mother "in passing" that she wanted to switch schools
column23: but her delivery was so offhand that at the time
column24: her mother casually advised against the switch. Nadine suffered on
column25: sobbing herself to sleep most nights and wishing that she would not wake up.Full of hope and ideas of escape from the bullies and their narrowness
column26: Nadine transferred to a specialty arts high school for ninth grade. Although the bullying ceased
column27: her anxiety symptoms paradoxically worsened. She felt even more unable to venture into public spaces and felt increasingly embarrassed by her inability to develop the sort of independence typical of a 15-year-old. She said she had begun to spend whole weekends "trapped" in her home and had become scared to even read by herself in the local park.Nadine's social anxiety had evolved into true agoraphobia. She had nightly nightmares about the bullies in her old school. Her preoccupation with suicide grew.Her parents had thought she would outgrow being shy and sought psychiatric help for her only after a teacher remarked that her anxiety and social isolation were keeping her from making the sort of grades and doing the sort of extracurricular activities that were necessary to get into a good college.Nadine described her mother as loud
column28: excitable
column29: aggressive
column30: and "a little frightening." Her father was a successful tax attorney who worked long hours. Nadine described him as shy in social situations ("He's more like me"). Nadine said she and her father sometimes joked that the goal of any evening was to avoid tipping the mother into a rage. Nadine added that she "never wanted to be anything like her mother."§Nadine may be diagnosed with Social Anxiety Disorder (Social Phobia)
column31: as per ICD-11 criteria. She exhibits intense fear of being humiliated in social situations which leads to avoidance behavior
column32: significant distress about speaking and interacting outside her home or school classes
column33: experiences physical symptoms like dizziness when anxious
column34: has thoughts of suicide due to feelings of trapped helplessness
column35: and shows signs of agoraphobia. The cultural/racial bullying she faced may exacerbate these issues but does not directly indicate dementia-related disinhibition or wandering as per ICD codes provided for those conditions. (Note: There is no direct link between the described symptoms and any of the specific ICD-11 diagnoses given in the context
column36: suggesting Nadine's condition falls outside these categories.)---------------------------

column1: 36§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Katharina Meyerbrï¿½ker

column1: 37§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Ryan E. Lawrence
column3: M.D.Peggy Isaac was a 41-year-old administrative assistant who was referred for an outpatient evaluation by her primary care physician with a chief complaint of "I'm always on edge." She lived alone and had never married or had children. She had never before seen a psychiatrist.Ms. Isaac had lived with her longtime boyfriend until 8 months earlier

column6: to economize

column13: she added
column14: "It's ridiculous. I honestly feel something terrible is going to happen in one of the aisles and no one will help me
column15: so I won't even go in." When in her apartment
column16: she could often relax and enjoy a good book or movie.Ms. Isaac said she had "always been a little nervous." Through much of kindergarten

column21: "I hated being single

column24: until the recent breakup

column26: jogged daily

column28: and had "no real complaints."On initial interview
column29: Ms. Isaac said she had been sad for a few weeks after her boyfriend left
column30: but denied ever having felt worthless

column35: with a Generalized Anxiety Disorder-7 score of 18
column36: indicating severe anxiety.§The diagnosis is Bipolar type II Disorder with a Current Episode Depressive Moderate Severity featuring Psychotic Symptoms (ICD-10 code not provided in context). The patient shows significant anxiety and avoidance behaviors
column37: which could overlap with aspects of disinhibition seen in dementia but the primary issues relate to mood fluctuation typical for bipolar II. However
column38: there's no clear evidence from this case description that aligns fully with Disinhibition in Dementia (ICD-10 code 6D86.5). The patient does not report cognitive decline or significant social convention disregard as seen typically in dementia cases. Therefore
column39: the primary diagnosis is Bipolar type II Depression with psychotic symptoms rather than Disinhibition due to Dementia.

column1: 38§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Andrea DiMartini
column3: M.D.A psychiatric transplant liaison service was called to evaluate Robert Jennings
column4: a 50- year-old married white man
column5: for a liver transplant in the context of an alcohol use disorder
column6: advanced cirrhosis

column9: he had been unaware that his alcohol consumption was seriously damaging his health and was shocked to learn that he would eventually require a liver transplant. Upon discharge
column10: he began an addiction treatment program that was mandatory for him to be listed for possible transplantation.Outpatient psychiatric consultation was requested by the transplant team after the patient's family expressed concern that he had recently become increasingly irritable and anxious and seemed to be having difficulty coping with the requirements for transplantation. Mr. Jennings's primary care physician had recently prescribed alprazolam 0.5 mg as needed for his anxiety. This was initially helpful
column11: but after several days his family noticed he seemed more irritable
column12: lethargic
column13: and forgetful.When interviewed
column14: the patient said that he had been tired for months prior to the diagnosis and that the fatigue had hampered his ability to work (his job required making deliveries for a shipping firm). Although the diagnosis had been a shock
column15: he said he had left the hospital feeling "great
column16: better than I'd felt in years." For about a week after discharge
column17: he described having enhanced energy and a sense of well-being
column18: but he then began to feel anxious and restless. He slept poorly
column19: unable to concentrate
column20: and worried constantly about his health
column21: finances
column22: and family. He became less engaged with his family and stopped watching movies
column23: normally his favorite pastime.He denied having nightmares
column24: flashbacks
column25: avoidant behaviors
column26: or racing thoughts. He also denied low mood
column27: tearfulness
column28: appetite changes
column29: anhedonia
column30: helplessness
column31: hopelessness
column32: or suicidality. He reported that he had started drinking daily 10 years earlier
column33: stating that he enjoyed the taste of beer and liked socializing with friends after work. He developed tolerance to alcohol
column34: needing to consume six to eight drinks per night to achieve the same effect. He described some withdrawal symptoms in themorning but did not drink during work hours; he underwent random testing due to his job as a truck driver. He did miss some family activities
column35: preferring to drink
column36: and this had been a source of marital conflict. He admitted feeling guilty about his alcohol use and its impact on him and his family. He denied using any alcohol since his hospitalization. He admitted to anger over having to undergo addiction counseling and had argued with the transplant team about this requirement. He denied having been an anxious person and considered himself able to handle most of life's challenges without being overwhelmed.His family confirmed his description of himself and viewed his recent behavior as uncharacteristic.On mental status examination
column37: Mr. Jennings was a thin
column38: jaundiced
column39: tired-appearing man. His gait was normal
column40: but he was fidgety while seated. He maintained eye contact and responded appropriately
column41: although he repeatedly made comments like
column42: "Something isn't right" and "It's not all in my head." His affect was anxious and irritable
column43: and his speech was terse. He appeared distracted but denied confusion and disorientation. He had no delusions or hallucinations. His thoughts were logical and coherent
column44: without disorganization

He scored in the normal range for Trail Making Test A and B but asked to have the instructions repeated for Trails B.§The patient may be experiencing disinhibition associated with underlying undiagnosed dementia (ICD-11 Code: F06.5). The lack of restraint
