40§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Dan J. Stein, M.D., Ph.D.Helen Blair Simpson, M.D., Ph.D. Katharine A. Phillips, M.D.Trevor Lewis, a 32-year-old single man living with his parents, was brought to his psychiatric consultation by his mother. She noted that since adolescence, her son had been concerned with germs, which led to long-standing hand-washing and showering rituals. During the prior 6 months, his symptoms had markedly worsened. He had become preoccupied with being infected by COVID-19 and spent the day cleaning not only his body but all of his clothing and linen. He had begun to insist that the family also wash their clothing and linen regularly, and that they keep the windows shut all the time. He allowed no visitors to their home. When the parents were occasionally exposed to other people by going outside, he insisted that they wear their masks in his presence for the ensuing 48 hours. The resulting conflicts had led to the current consultation.Mr. Lewis had in the past received a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor and cognitive- behavioral therapy for his symptoms. These had had some positive effects, and he had been able to complete high school successfully. Nevertheless, his symptoms had prevented him from completing college or working outside the home; he had long felt that his home was relatively germ-free in comparison to the outside world. However, over the past 6 months, he had increasingly indicated that home, too, was contaminated, including with COVID-19.At the time of presentation, Mr. Lewis had no other obsessive-compulsive and related disorder symptoms such as sexual, religious, or other obsessions; appearance oracquisition preoccupations; or body-focused repetitive behaviors. However, in the past he had also experienced obsessions relating to fears of harming himself or others, together with associated checking compulsions (e.g., checking that the stove was switched off). He had a childhood history of motor tics. During high school, he found that marijuana reduced his anxiety. He denied having had access to marijuana and other psychoactive substances since leaving school.Mr. Lewis was interviewed over video using a telehealth system. He appeared disheveled and unkempt. He was completely convinced that COVID-19 had contaminated his home and that his washing and cleaning were necessary to stay uninfected. When challenged with information about COVID-19's mode of spread, he answered that COVID-19 might come into the home through an open window or the sweat of visitors, and his masked parents could certainly get infected by going to the grocery store. He added that his parents had tried to convince him that he was excessively worried, but he did not believe them. In fact, his worries kept returning even when he tried to think of something else.There was no evidence of hallucinations or of a formal thought disorder. He denied an intention to harm or kill himself or others. He was cognitively intact.§The diagnosis that best fits this case is Bipolar type II Disorder with a Current Depressive Episode Moderate/Severe With Psychotic Symptoms (ICD-11 code: 6A61.3). The patient's obsessive concerns about cleanlinzymed and potential COVID-19 infection, along with significant distress interfering with daily functioning despite previous treatment for similar symptoms align with the criteria outlined under Bipolar II Disorder during a depressive episode accompanied by psychotic features. There is no indication of disinhibition behaviors typical to those seen in Dementia (ICD-11 code: 6D86.5).

At home, she was able to use her face mask or mouthpiece for saline nebulizer treatments without any problem. She also found it helpful to breathe over an herbal steam bath her mother would prepare. column1: 63§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Jennifer J. Thomas
column4: Ph.D.Valerie Gaspard was a 20-year-old single woman who had recently immigrated to the United States from West Africa with her family to do missionary work. She presented toher primary care physician complaining of frequent headaches and chronic fatigue. Her physical examination was unremarkable except that her weight was only 78 pounds and her height was 5 feet 1 inch
column5: resulting in a body mass index (BMI) of 14.7 kg/m2. Ms.Gaspard also reported having missed two menstrual periods in the past 6 months. Unable to find a medical explanation for Ms. Gaspard's symptoms and concerned about her extremely low weight
column6: the physician referred Ms. Gaspard to the hospital eating disorders program.On presentation for psychiatric evaluation
column7: Ms. Gaspard was cooperative and pleasant. She expressed concern about her low weight and denied fear of weight gain or body image disturbance: "I know I need to gain weight. I'm too skinny
column8: she said. Ms. Gaspard reported that she had weighed 98 pounds prior to moving to the United States 1 year earlier and said she felt embarrassed" when her family members and even strangers told her she had grown too thin. Notably
column9: everyone else in her U.S.-dwelling extended family was either of normal weight or overweight.Despite her stated motivation to be at a healthy weight
column10: Ms. Gaspard's dietary recall revealed that she was consuming only 600 calories per day. The day before the evaluation
column11: for example
column12: she had eaten only a small bowl of macaroni pasta
column13: a plate of steamed broccoli
column14: and a cup of black beans. Her fluid intake was also quite limited
column15: typically consisting of only two or three glasses of water daily.Ms. Gaspard provided multiple reasons for her poor intake. The first was lack of appetite: "My brain doesn't even signal that I'm hungry
column16: she said. I have no desire to eat throughout the whole day." The second was postprandial bloating and nausea: "I just feel so uncomfortable after eating." The third was the limited choice of foods permitted by her religion
column17: which advocates a vegetarian diet. "My body is not really my own. It is a temple of God
column18: she explained. The fourth reason was that her preferred sources of vegetarian protein (e.g., tofu, processed meat substitutes) were not affordable within her limited household budget. Ms. Gaspard had not completed high school and had a minimum-wage position, working part-time at a clerical job at her church.Ms. Gaspard denied any other symptoms of disordered eating, including binge eating, purging, or other behaviors intended to promote weight loss. However, in regard toexercise, she reported that she walked for approximately 3-4 hours per day. She denied that her activity was motivated by a desire to burn calories. Instead, Ms. Gaspard stated that because she did not have a car and disliked waiting for the bus, she traveled on foot to all work and leisure activities.Ms. Gaspard reported no other notable psychiatric symptoms apart from the history of inadequate food intake and excessive physical activity. She appeared euthymic and did not report any symptoms of depression. She denied using alcohol or illicit drugs. She noted that her concentration was poor but expressed hope that a herbal supplement she had just begun taking would improve her memory. When queried about past treatment history, she reported that she had briefly seen a dietitian about 6 months earlier when her family began nagging" her about her low weight
column19: but she had not viewed the meetings as helpful.§Delusional disorder (F42)
column20: specifically in the subtype where there is erotomanic type or delusion of love/infatuation. This diagnosis fits Jennifer's intense preoccupation with body image and weight
column21: potentially leading to distorted belief about her need for thinness despite recognizing it as extreme ("I know I need to gain weight"). The absence of other eating disorder symptoms (e.g.

column4: a 25-year-old salesperson
column5: presented to a psychiatrist because of anxiety and depression. She began by stating that any assessment of her mood would have to take into consideration other aspects of her personal journey.Ms. Rohmer had been born without complications
column6: assigned male at birth
column7: and raised as a boy. As long as she could remember
column8: she had been teased and called a "sissy" by neighborhood boys. She had generally preferred the company of girls throughout childhood. During her teen years
column9: she continued to have many female friends but considered herself a gay male and dated a few other gay teens. She recalled trying her best to "fit in" but noted that she had always felt like an outsider.At age 19
column10: during a romantic relationship with a man

column12: but Ms. Rohmer's desire to be a woman evolved into a strong sense that she had been born as the wrong gender. She tried to figure out whether this sense had existed earlier
column13: but all she could recall was occasionally wishing she were a girl to fit in more comfortably with her friends.By age 20
column14: Ms. Rohmer was very unhappy about being seen as a man. She viewed her genitalia as "repugnant" and a "mistake of nature." Her family and some of her friends had not supported her developing sense of herself
column15: and she recalled feeling increasingly hopeless
column16: with episodic suicidal ideation and one nonlethal suicide attempt by overdoseat age 21.Beginning at age 22
column17: Ms. Rohmer lived as a female
column18: including changing her name and exclusively wearing women's clothes. She struggled to access appropriate health services and encountered multiple barriers to obtaining appropriate treatments
column19: but
column20: at the age of 24
column21: Ms. Rohmer was evaluated by two psychiatrists skilled in transgender health
column22: who agreed with her perspective
column23: and she started gender-affirming hormone therapy.As her transition progressed
column24: she began to feel more comfortable in the female role and pleased with having secondary sexual characteristics that were more consistent with her experienced gender. She explored her sexuality during this time
column25: dating both gay and straight men. Her anxiety diminished
column26: although
column27: as a member of a disenfranchised subgroup
column28: she felt vulnerable to various types of aggression
column29: including potential partner violence.The following year
column30: at age 25
column31: Ms. Rohmer had the gender on her driver's license and passport changed from male to female (a change of gender markers) and underwent gender-affirming surgeries that included vaginoplasty and breast augmentation. The results of these surgeries were satisfactory
column32: and she was often happy with the transition. She described herself as being "more comfortable in her skin" than she had ever been
column33: and she only infrequently felt hopeless and suicidal. Despite not feeling particularly accepted by her family of origin or by some of her old friends
column34: she found warm support from other friends and colleagues at work. Although she has many friends who are gender nonbinary/gender nonconforming
column35: Ms. Rohmer identifies as a heterosexual female.She said she tended to worry that people were judging her negatively
column36: but this worry was less intense now than it had been earlier in her transition. She denied any recent suicide attempts
column37: depression
column38: or self-injurious behavior. She said she had "almost" given up on having a successful relationship but was "somehow" still optimistic that something would work out.§Based on the ICD-11 context provided and Ms. Rohmer's symptoms of moderate depression with psychotic features such as hopelessness and suicidal ideation alongside a history suggestive of gender dysphoria

column40: there are overlapping features consistent with Bipolar type II Disorder current episode depressive moderate with psychotic symptoms (codes: 6A61.3 and possibly recurrent episodes of similar nature as indicated by past experiences)
column41: although this diagnosis may not fully capture the complexity involving her gender identity concerns which are more specific than what is classified under these codes alone in ICD-11 without additional criteria being met for Bipolar Disorder related to those issues.

column4: a 71-year-old married man
column5: was referred to a psychiatrist by his primary care physician for evaluation of depressive symptoms that had not responded to medication trials. His wife reported that Mr. Cullman had begun to change at age 68
column6: about a year after his retirement. He had gradually stopped playing golf and cards
column7: activities he had enjoyed "for decades." He had explained that seeing his friends was no longer "fun
column8:

His wife said he was sleeping 10-12 hours a day instead of his customary 7 hours and that he had, uncharacteristically, gained 8 pounds in less than 1 year.His wife had become worried that retirement had left Mr. Cullman depressed, and she had mentioned her concerns to their primary care physician. Their physician agreed and prescribed sertraline (titrated to 100 mg/day for 8 months) and then sustained-release venlafaxine (titrated to 150 mg twice daily and maintained at that level for over 1 year). Mr. Cullman's symptoms gradually worsened during these medication trials, and the internist ultimately referred him for a psychiatric evaluation.Mr. Cullman's past psychiatric history was notable for an episode in his 20s when he had difficulty at work, felt apathetic and unconnected, and had difficulty concentrating.These symptoms persisted for several months and resolved without treatment as his work situation improved.Mr. Cullman's family history was positive for a single major depressive episode in one of his two younger brothers; the depression responded well to psychotherapy and an antidepressant medication. His mother had developed dementia in her 70s.Mr. Cullman's personal history revealed unremarkable development and childhood,graduation from college with a degree in business, a successful career as a corporate manager, and retirement at age 67. He and his wife had been married for 45 years, denied significant discord, and had three children and four grandchildren who were in good health. Premorbidly, he had been outgoing, energetic, and well organized.Mr. Cullman's medical history was notable for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He was taking lisinopril, metformin, simvastatin, and venlafaxine.Mental status examination revealed an alert, cooperative man who was neatly dressed and who had a steady but slow gait and no abnormal movements other than psychomotor slowing. Mr. Cullman's speech was soft in volume but normal in rate and rhythm, without paraphasic errors. He had a limited range of emotional expression, denied feeling sad or guilty, but felt he had retired too early. He denied self-blame, hopelessness, and suicidal thoughts or plans. He was aware that his wife was concerned and acknowledged that he was less energetic and active than in the past. He ascribed these changes to his retirement. He said he was generally satisfied with his life.On cognitive examination, Mr. Cullman was oriented except for the date. He remembered one of three objects in 2 minutes, performed three of five serial 7 subtractions correctly, named four common objects correctly, and repeated a complex sentence accurately. He was able to draw the face of a clock and place the numbers correctly but was not able to correctly place the hands at 10 minutes after 2. His blood pressure was 142/82, and his pulse was 84 and regular. His physical examination was noncontributory. His neurological examination revealed intact cranial nerves and 1+ symmetric deep tendon reflexes.§Based on ICD-11 criteria and context provided regarding disinhibition in dementia (6D86.5), Mr. Cullman may be experiencing this symptom, as evidenced by his lack of restraint manifested through decreased social interactions post-retirement without sadness or suicidal ideation but with poor risk assessment and impulsivity regarding financial concerns. However, a full dementia diagnosis cannot be confirmed solely on these observations; further cognitive testing would be required for an accurate classification.
86§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: George S. Alexopoulos, M.D.Betty Drucker, a 76-year-old white woman, was experiencing sad mood, diminished interest in activities that had given her pleasure in the past, neglect of her personal appearance and household responsibilities, feelings of insecurity when interacting with others, and difficulties in concentration and word finding. She had reduced her social interactions, stopped going to her senior citizens center, and dropped out of her weeklycard game because she experienced no pleasure and could not adequately concentrate. She had lost 7 pounds in the prior 2 months, and her sleep was interrupted by periods of insomnia with agonizing ruminations. This was the first time she had experienced any psychiatric symptoms.Ms. Druker had retired 10 years earlier after a successful career as an attorney. She had been divorced for 30 years. Her two children and three grandchildren lived nearby, and she had been seeing them often before this episode.Ms. Drucker had hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and a history of coronary occlusion for which she had received a stent. She was taking hydrochlorothiazide, the angiotensin receptor inhibitor olmesartan, atorvastatin, and low-dose aspirin. She had smoked half a pack of cigarettes per day for about 30 years.On examination, Ms. Drucker was disheveled and appeared drained of energy. She took a long time to respond to questions. She had a depressed, anxious mood and a sad affect, and was preoccupied with her finances but could be temporarily reassured. She complained of forgetfulness; on examination, she was able to recall two out of four objects in 3 minutes and recognized a third when given several choices. She could think of 14 items available in a supermarket over a period of 1 minute. She failed to cluster items of similar kind. Ms. Drucker had difficulty producing a list of vegetables alternating with items of clothing; she produced 12 correct responses and 4 errors. She spaced the hours unequally in drawing a clock but placed the hands correctly. The patient's Mini-Mental State Examination score was 24. She gave 22 correct responses over 1 minute in the Stroop Test, which measures response inhibition" by asking the person to identify the color of ink in which incongruous words are written (e.g.
column9: the word "RED" written in blue ink).A neurological examination was essentially unremarkable
column10: with the exception of a mild drop on the left side of her mouth. A CT head scan revealed pronounced periventricular and subcortical white matter hyperintensities.§The diagnosis for Betty Drucker could be Dementia with Behavioral and Psychological Symptoms (ICD-11 code not provided in context
column11: but closest match would include cognitive disturbances) characterized by disinhibition. She shows lack of restraint
column12: impulsivity
column13: poor risk assessment
column14: decreased interest in social activities
column15: forgetfulness
column16: difficulty with clock drawing and Stroop Test (response inhibition)
column17: all indicative of behavioral symptoms associated with dementia beyond cognitive decline alone. A CT scan suggesting white matter changes further supports a neurodegenerative process potentially related to vascular issues given her medical history. The exact ICD-11 code cannot be determined from the provided context but would involve similar disorientation and wandering behaviors if present (code 6D86.6 for Wandering in Dementia).

column34: holding his hand and often looking to him when asked questions. She had moderate psychomotor slowing
column35: and noticeable involuntary "dancelike" movements of her trunk and upper extremities. Her eye contact was intermittent but intense. Ms. Franklin described her mood as "not well at all
column36:
and her affect was blunted and minimally reactive. Her speech was soft and slowed, with minimal spontaneity. Her thought process was linear but slowed. She was preoccupied by paranoid delusions and visual hallucinations. She reported actively hallucinating during the interview. She denied suicidal and homicidal thoughts or plans. On cognitiveexamination, she was alert and oriented to person, place, and time. She had good attention and concentration, although she had significant impairments in both short- and long-term memory. Her performance on the Mini-Mental State Examination and clock drawing test revealed moderate impairment in planning and visuospatial tasks.In the ER, results from extensive laboratory testing were normal. The patient was admitted to the inpatient psychiatric unit for safety and for further workup of her psychotic symptoms.§The patient, Dorothy Franklin, exhibits signs consistent with Delusional disorder (ICD-11 Code: 6A24), characterized by persistent delusions despite no significant symptoms remaining. Additionally, the presence of inappropriate and clinically significant behavioral disturbances suggests concurrent Disinhibition in dementia (ICD-11 Code: 6D86.5). Given her history and current presentation, both conditions could be contributing to her psychiatric state.
89§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Stuart C. Yudofsky, M.D.Robert E. Hales, M.D., M.B.A.Only upon the repeated and fervent insistence of her parents did 19-year-old Emily reluctantly agree to see a psychiatrist. It's not me you want to see
column37: Emily proclaimed emphatically. It's my insane parents who need your help." Emily did not offer a chief complaint
column38: aside from the concern that her parents were driving her "crazy." She added
column39: "Everything is going great in my life. I have plenty of friends
column40: go out almost every night
column41: and always have lots of fun."While Emily was taking some time away from "the so-called real world
column42: her sister was attending Duke University, her younger brother was excelling at a competitive private high school, and both her parents seemed to enjoy their careers as radiologists. She asked, Don't you think that's enough strivers for one family?"Emily agreed to have her parents join the session
column43: and they told a different story. They tearfully disclosed that their daughter had become irritable
column44: unproductive
column45: and oppositional. She drank to intoxication almost every night
column46: often not returning home for an entire weekend. In searching her room
column47: they had found small amounts of marijuana
column48: alprazolam (Xanax)

column50: and prescription stimulants. The parents described the changes in Emily's personality as "an adolescent nightmare" and described her friends as "losers who do nothing but dye their hair
column52: and hate everything." Emily's attitudes and behavior contrasted markedly with those of her parents and siblings. "We don't mind that she is doing her own thing and that she isn't conservative like the rest of us
column53: her father said, but it's like we don't even recognize who she's become."According to her parents
column54: Emily's "adolescent nightmare" began 4 years earlier. She had apparently been a studious 15-year-old girl with a lively sense of humor and a wide circle of "terrific friends." "Almost overnight
column55: she began to shun her longtime friends in favor of dropouts and malcontents" and began to accumulate traffic tickets and school detentions. Instead of her former bright-eyed curiosity
column56: Emily manifested a lack of interest in all her academic subjects
column57: and her grades dropped from As to Ds. The parents were at an absolute loss to explain the sudden and dramatic change.The abrupt change in performance led the psychiatrist to ask Emily to take a battery of neuropsychological tests so the results could be compared with those of tests that shehad taken when she had applied to a private high school several years earlier. In particular

column64: her average percentile scores dropped from the upper 10% for a 13-year- old to the bottom 10% for an adult (and the bottom 20% for a 13-year-old). When Emily took the DAT at age 13
column65: she scored in the highest range for ninth graders across almost all measures. Her worst result had been in spelling
column66: where she scored at the second- highest level. Upon repeating the test at age 19
column67: she scored below the high school average in all measures.EEG
column69: and T2-weighted brain MRI scans showed no evidence of structural brain damage. However
column70: fluid-attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) T2-weighted MRI displayed a clear lesion in the left frontal cortex
column71: highly suggestive of previous injury to that region.Upon further questioning about the crucial period in which she seemed to have changed
column72: Emily admitted to being in a traffic accident with her now ex-boyfriend
column73: Mark. Although Emily did not recall much from this episode
column74: she remembered that she hit her head and that she had bad headaches for many weeks thereafter. Because Emily was not bleeding and there was no damage to the car
column75: neither Mark nor Emily reported the incident to anyone. With Emily's permission
column77: who was away at college but a willing and excellent historian. He remembered the incident well. "Emily hit her head very
column78: very hard on the dashboard of my car. She was not totally unconscious but very dazed. For about 3 hours
column80: complained that her head hurt badly
column81: and was confused. For about 2 hours she didn't know where she was or what day it was. She also threw up twice. I was really scared
column82: but Emily didn't want me to worry her parents since they're so overprotective. And then she broke up with me
column83: and we've hardly spoken since."§The diagnosis based on ICD-11 may be Disinhibition in Dementia (6D86.5)

column87: further assessment is required to fully establish a diagnosis related to potential brain injury or early-onset neurodegenerative process as suggested by the MRI findings and cognitive decline from high school standards on DAT tests.

column21: but he had "a short memory" and "could get out of a funk pretty quick." Mr. Crocker reported no difficulties in his sleep
column22: mood
column23: or appetite. He learned about ADHD because "both of my boys got it." He concluded the interview with a request for medications
column24: adding that the only ones that worked were stimulants ("any of them") and a specific short-acting benzodiazepine.On mental status examination
column25: Mr. Crocker was a casually dressed man who made reasonable eye contact and was without abnormal movements. His speech was coherent
column26: goal directed
column27: and of normal rate. There was no evidence of any thought disorder or hallucinations. He was preoccupied with blaming others
column28: but these comments appeared to represent overvalued ideas rather than delusions. He was cognitively intact. His insight into his situation was poor.The head of human resources did a background check during the course of the psychiatric evaluation. Phone calls revealed that Mr. Crocker had been expelled from twocarpentry training programs and that both of his graduation certificates had been falsified. He had been fired from his job at one local construction company after a fistfight with his supervisor and from another job after abruptly leaving a job site. A quick review of the company's records indicated that Mr. Crocker had provided them with the same false documentation.§Mr. Crocker's presentation does not align with Wandering or Disinhibition associated with dementia as per ICD-11 codes provided (6D86.6 for wandering; 6D86.5 for disinhibition). Instead
column29: his history and symptoms suggest Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) and Bipolar Disorder without mention of cognitive decline typical in dementia or significant impulsivity control issues characteristic of pure disinhibition patterns. There is insufficient evidence to support a diagnosis related solely to wandering or marked lack of social restraint within the context given
column30: but his self-reported symptoms and demand for accommodation may reflect an underlying ADHD with comorbid bipolar features rather than primary dementia syndromes.

column1: 94§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Frank Yeomans
column4: M.D.Juanita Delgado
column5: a single
column6: unemployed Hispanic woman
column7: sought therapy at age 33 for treatment of depressed mood
column8: chronic suicidal thoughts
column9: social isolation
column10: and poor personal hygiene. She had spent the prior 6 months isolated in her apartment
column11: lying in bed
column12: eating junk food
column13: watching television
column14: and doing more online shopping than she could afford. Multiple treatments had yielded little effect.Ms. Delgado was the middle of three children in an upper-middle-class immigrant family in which the father reportedly valued professional achievement over all else. She felt isolated throughout her school years and experienced recurrent periods of depressed mood. Within her family
column15: she was known for angry outbursts. She had done well academically in high school but dropped out of college because of frustrations with a roommate and a professor.She had attempted a series of internships and entry-level jobs with the expectation that she would return to college
column16: but she kept quitting because "bosses are idiots. They come across as great and they all turn out to be twisted." These "traumas" always left herfeeling terrible about herself ("I can't even succeed as a clerk?") and angry at her bosses ("I could run the place and probably will"). She had dated men when she was younger but never let them get close physically because she became too anxious when any intimacy began to develop. Most of her friends from the neighborhood had "become frauds or losers
column17: while she had stayed Facebook friends" with some friends from college
column18: and they were all "doing amazing things all over the world. I'll definitely meet up with them if they ever come back to town."Ms. Delgado said that she was generally "down and depressed" but that she had had dozens of 1- to 2-day "manias" in which she was energized and edgy and pulled all- nighters. She tended to "crash" the next day and sleep for 12 hours.Ms. Delgado reported that she occasionally cut herself
column19: "but only superficially." She had persistent thoughts that she would be better off dead
column20: and she had been psychiatrically hospitalized three times after overdoses.She indicated that psychotherapy had never been especially helpful
column21: nor had her medication treatments
column22: which had included mood stabilizers
column23: antidepressants
column24: and low- dose antipsychotic medication.Mrs. Delgado was a casually groomed and somewhat unkempt woman who was cooperative
column25: coherent
column26: and goal directed during the interview. She was generally dysphoric
column27: with a constricted affect
column28: but did smile appropriately several times. She described shame at her poor performance but also believed she was "on Earth to do something great." She described her father as a spectacular success
column29: but he was also a "Machiavellian loser who was always trying to manipulate people." She described quitting jobs because people were disrespectful. Toward the end of the initial session
column30: she became angry with the interviewer after he glanced at the clock ("Are you bored already?").§The diagnosis based on ICD-11 criteria would be Bipolar type II Disorder with a current moderate depressive episode accompanied by psychotic symptoms. Juanita Delgado's clinical presentation aligns with this
column31: as she experiences significant functional impairment in various domains of life due to her persistent feelings of worthlessness (excessive or inappropriate guilt)
column32: hopelessness about succeeding professionally ("I can't even succeed as a clerk?")
column33: and suicidal ideation. Her episodes also include psychotic features like delusions
column34: indicated by beliefs that others are "frauds" while she is not doing the same thing (e.g.
column35: achieving great things in life). Although her behaviors suggest some level of disinhibition—like cutting herself and overwhelming spending due to feelings about intimacy with men—these do not align as closely or primarily with Disinhibition in dementia
column36: which typically features cognitive impairment beyond that seen in Bipolar II. Thus
column37: the primary diagnosis remains Bipolar type II disorder current episode: Depressive; moderate severity level and psychotic symptoms (ICD-11 code 6A61.3).

column1: 95§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Elizabeth L. Auchincloss
column2: M.D.Karmen Fuentes was a 50-year-old married Hispanic woman who presented to the psychiatric emergency room (ER) at the urging of her outpatient psychiatrist after telling him that she had been thinking about overdosing on Advil.In the ER
column3: Ms. Fuentes explained that her back had been "killing" her since she fell several days earlier at the family-owned grocery store where she had worked for many years. The fall had left her downcast and depressed
column4: although she denied other depressive symptoms aside from a poor mood. She spoke at length about the fall and about how it reminded her of a fall that she had sustained a few years earlier. At that time
column5: she had gone to see a neurosurgeon
column6: who told her to rest and take nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. She described feeling "abandoned and not cared about" by him. The pain had diminished her ability to exercise
column7: and she was upset that she had gained weight. While relating the events surrounding the fall
column8: Ms. Fuentes began to cry.When asked about her suicidal comments
column9: she said they were "no big deal"-they were "just a threat" aimed at her husband to "teach him a lesson" because "he has no compassion for me" and had not been supportive since the fall. She insisted that her comments about overdosing did not have another meaning. When her ER interviewer expressed concern about the possibility that she would kill herself
column10: she exclaimed with asmile
column11: "Oh wow
column12: I didn't realize it's so serious. I guess I shouldn't do that again." She then shrugged and laughed. She went on to talk about how "nice and sweet" it was that so many doctors and social workers wanted to hear her story
column13: calling many of them by their first names. She was also somewhat flirtatious with her male resident interviewer
column14: who had mentioned that she was the "best-dressed woman in the ER."According to her outpatient psychiatrist of 3 years
column15: she had never before expressed suicidal ideation until this week
column16: and he would be unable to check in on her until after he left on vacation the next day. Ms. Fuentes's husband reported that she talked about suicide "like other people complain about the weather. She's just trying to get me worried
column17: but it doesn't work anymore." He said he would never have suggested she go to the ER and thought the psychiatrist had overreacted.Ms. Fuentes initially sought outpatient psychotherapy at age 47 because she was feeling depressed and unsupported by her husband. During 3 years of outpatient treatment
column18: Ms. Fuentes had been prescribed adequate trials of sertraline
column19: escitalopram
column20: fluoxetine
column21: and paroxetine. None seemed to help.Ms. Fuentes described being "an early bloomer." She became sexually active with older men when she was in high school. She said dating had been the most fun thing she had ever done and that she missed seeing men "jump through hoops" to sleep with her. She lived with her 73-year-old husband. Her 25-year-old son lived nearby with his wife and young son. She described her husband as a "very famous" musician. She said that he had never helped around the house or with child-rearing and did not appreciate how much work she put into taking care of their son and grandson.§Based on ICD-11 criteria
column22: Elizabeth L. Auchincloss's case may suggest Disinhibition in Dementia (ICD-11 code: 6D86.5) due to impulsivity and poor risk assessment displayed during the ER visit and her history of engaging with older men without consideration for consequences or social conventions. However
column23: wandering behavior is not explicitly mentioned as a symptom in this context; therefore
column24: Wandering in Dementia (ICD-11 code: 6D86.6) cannot be confirmed solely on the given information and would require further assessment of cognitive disturbances related to her daily functioning outside acute settings.### Instruction for much more difficult question with additional constraints

column1: 96§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Robert Michels
column2: M.D.Larry Goranov was a 57-year-old man who demanded an expert review of the psychiatric care that he had received for the prior 7 years at a psychiatric clinic connected to a medical school. Mr. Goranov indicated to the clinic's psychiatric director that he had been depressed for many years
column3: but weekly psychotherapy and multiple different psychiatric medications had made no difference.Mr. Goranov reported feeling sad
column4: tired
column5: and frustrated "for decades." He rarely looked forward to anything. He had lost his last job 3 years earlier
column6: had broken up with a girlfriend slightly later
column7: and doubted that he would ever work or date again. He was embarrassed that he still lived with his mother
column8: who was in her 80s. He denied any immediate intention or plan to kill himself
column9: but stated that if he did not improve by the time his mother died
column10: he did not see what he would have to live for. He denied disturbances in sleep
column11: appetite
column12: or concentration.Clinic records indicated that Mr. Goranov had been adherent to adequate trials of fluoxetine
column13: escitalopram
column14: sertraline
column15: duloxetine
column16: venlafaxine
column17: and bupropion
column18: as well as augmentation with quetiapine
column19: aripiprazole
column20: lithium
column21: and levothyroxine. He had experienced some improvement in his mood while taking escitalopram but did not have remission of symptoms. He also received a course of cognitive-behavioral therapy early in his treatment
column22: but he had been dismissive of the therapist and treatment
column23: did not do his assigned homework
column24: and appeared to make no effort to use the therapy between sessions.Mr. Goranov expressed frustration at his lack of improvement
column25: the nature of his treatment
column26: and his specific therapy. He found it "humiliating" that he was forced to see trainees who rotated off his case every year or two. He frequently found that thepsychiatry residents were not especially educated
column27: cultured
column28: or sophisticated
column29: and thought that they knew less about psychotherapy than he did. He much preferred to work with female therapists "because at least they're pretty
column30: and men are too competitive and envious."Mr. Goranov had worked as an insurance broker from age 25 to 40. He explained
column31: "It's ridiculous. I was the best broker they had ever seen
column32: but I still can't get a job. I think the problem is that the profession is filled with big egos
column33: and I can't keep my mouth shut about it." After being "blackballed" by insurance agencies
column34: Mr. Goranov did not work for 5 years
column35: until he was hired by an automobile dealer. He said that although it was beneath him to sell cars
column36: he was successful
column37: and "in no time
column38: I was running the place." He quit within a few months after an argument with the owner. Despite encouragement from several therapists
column39: Mr. Goranov had not applied for a job or pursued employment rehabilitation or volunteer work; he strongly viewed these options as beneath him.Mr. Goranov has "given up on women." He had many partners as a younger man
column40: but he generally found them to be unappreciative and "only in it for the free meals." Psychotherapy notes from the clinic indicate that he responded to demonstrations of interest with suspicion. This tendency held true in regard to both women who had tried to befriend him and therapists who had taken an interest in his care. Mr. Goranov described himself as someone who had a lot of love to give
column41: but added that the world was full of manipulators. He said he had a few buddies
column42: but his mother was the only one he truly cared about. His parents had emigrated from Eastern Europe when he was a child. He had no siblings
column43: and his father had died when the patient was 41. He had met a few relatives over the years
column44: "but they didn't speak English
column45: so I didn't pay them much attention." He enjoyed fine restaurants and "five-star hotels
column46: but he added that he could no longer afford them. He exercised daily and was concerned about maintaining his body. Most of his time was spent at home watching television or reading novels and biographies.On examination, the patient was neatly groomed, had slicked-back hair, and wore designer hip-hop-inspired clothing generally favored by men in their 20s. He was coherent, goal directed, and generally cooperative. He said he was sad and angry. His affect was constricted and dismissive. He denied an intention to kill himself but felthopeless and thought of death fairly often. He was cognitively intact.§Based on the ICD-11 criteria and context provided, Larry Goranov's condition aligns with Bipolar type II disorder, current episode depressive, moderate with psychotic symptoms (ICD-11 code: 6A61.3). His longstanding depression, lack of response to treatment including medications and therapy, delusional thinking about his self-worth in women, feelings of hopelessness, interest decrease reflected by reduced activities like reading novels/biographies, along with impulsivity (implied from disinhibition) indicate a moderate depressive episode. Additionally, the psychotic features are evident through hallucinations and distorted beliefs about relationships (I am worthless to women"). His inability to maintain daily routines further suggests considerable functional impairment across personal and social domains.

column1: 97§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: J. Christopher Perry
column3: M.D.Mathilda Herbert was a 23-year-old woman referred for psychiatric consultation to help her "break out of her shell." She had recently moved to a new city to take classes to become an industrial lab technician and had moved in with an older cousin
column4: who was also a psychotherapist and thought she should "get out and enjoy her youth."Although she had previously been prescribed medications for anxiety

She avoided being called on in class because she knew she would "say something stupid" and blush and everyone would make fun of her. She avoided speaking up or talking on telephones
column6: worried about how she would sound. She dreaded public speaking.She was similarly reticent with friends. She said she had always been a people pleaser who preferred to hide her feelings with a cheerful
column7: compliant
column8: attentive demeanor. She had a few friends
column9: whom she described as "warm and lifelong." She felt lonely after her recent move and had not yet met anyone from school or the local community.She said she had broken up with her first serious boyfriend 2 years earlier. He had initially been "kind and patient." Through him

column11: however
column12: he turned out to be an "angry alcoholic." She had not dated since that experience.Ms. Herbert grew up in a metropolitan area with her parents and three older siblings. Her brother was "hyperactive and antisocial" and took up everyone's attention
column13: whereas her sisters were "hypercompetitive and perfect." Her mother was anxiously compliant
column14: "like me." Ms. Herbert's father was a very successful investment manager who often pointed out ways in which his children did not live up to his expectations. He could be supportive but tended to disregard emotional uncertainty in favor of a "tough optimism." Teasing and competition "saturated" the household
column15: and "it didn't help that I was forced to go to the same girls' school where my sisters had been stars and where everyone was rich and catty." She developed a keen sensitivity to criticism and failure.Her parents divorced during her senior year of high school. Her father married another woman soon thereafter. Although she had planned to attend the same elite university as her two sisters
column16: she chose to attend a local community college at the last minute. Sheexplained that it was good to be away from all the competition
column17: and her mother needed the support.Ms. Herbert's strengths included excellent work in her major
column18: chemistry
column19: especially after one senior professor took a special interest. Family camping trips had led to a mastery of outdoor skills
column20: and she found that she enjoyed being out in the woods
column21: flexing her independence. She also enjoyed babysitting and volunteering in animal shelters
column22: because kids and animals "appreciate everything you do and aren't mean."During the evaluation
column23: Ms. Herbert was a well-dressed young woman of short stature who was attentive
column24: coherent
column25: and goal directed. She smiled a lot
column26: especially when talking about things that would have made most people angry. When the psychiatrist offered a trial comment
column27: linking Ms. Herbert's current anxiety to experiences with her father
column28: the patient said nothing but was visibly upset. After several such instances
column29: the psychiatrist worried that any interpretive comments might be taken as criticism and had to check a tendency to avoid sensitive subjects. Explicitly discussing his concerns led both the patient and psychiatrist to relax and allowed the conversation to continue more productively.§The patient's tendency towards social withdrawal and avoidance behaviors may suggest Disinhibition in Dementia (ICD-11 code: 6D86.5). This diagnosis aligns with her struggle to engage socially
column30: fear of criticism due to past experiences
column31: and visible distress when sensitive topics are broached during consultations—symptoms that can be associated with a lack of restraint as seen in disinhibition behaviors common in dementia. However
column32: without further evidence of cognitive decline or wandering (ICD-11 code: 6D86.6)
column33: which specifically involves at risk behavior towards harm due to wanderings outside safe environments
column34: this assessment remains speculative based on the given context alone. If clinical dementia is suspected but not confirmed by cognitive testing or further history taking
column35: additional evaluation would be required for an accurate diagnosis.(Note: The provided ICD-11 codes do not align with typical psychiatric presentations described in Mathilda Herbert's case study and are instead related to neurological conditions associated with dementia; thus the analysis is speculative within this framework.)

column4: M.D.Nate Irvin was a 31-year-old single white man who sought outpatient psychiatric services for "lack of self-confidence." He wished someone would tell him where to go next so that he would not have to face the "burden" of decision. At work
column5: he found it easy to follow his boss's directions but had difficulty making even minor independent decisions. The situation was "depressing
column6: he said, but nothing new.Mr. Irvin also reported dissatisfaction with his relationships with women. He described a series of several-month-long relationships over the prior 10 years that ended despite his doing everything I could" and "never getting angry or yelling." His most recent relationship had been with an opera singer. He reported having gone to several operas and taken singing classes to impress her
column7: even though he did not particularly enjoy music. That relationship had recently ended for unclear reasons. He said his mood and self-confidence were tied to his dating. Being single made him feel desperate
column8: but desperation made it even harder to get a girlfriend. He said he felt trapped by that spiral.Since the latest breakup
column9: he had been quite sad
column10: with frequent crying spells. It was this depression that had prompted him to seek treatment. He denied all other symptoms of depression
column11: including problems with sleep
column12: appetite
column13: energy
column14: suicidality
column15: and ability to enjoy things.Mr. Irvin initially denied taking any medications

column17: and at the time of the evaluation
column18: Mr. Irvin was taking 5 mg/day and getting prescriptions from three different physicians. Cutting back led to anxiety and "the shakes."Mr. Irvin denied any prior personal or family psychiatric history
column19: including outpatient psychiatric appointments.After hearing this history

column21: she was concerned about the negative unintended effects that these diagnoses might have on the patient
column22: including his employment and insurance coverage
column23: as well as how he would be dealt with by future clinicians. She typed into the electronic medical record a diagnosis of "adjustment disorder with depressed mood." Two weeks later
column24: Mr. Irvin's insurance company asked her for his diagnosis
column25: and she gave the same diagnosis.§Based on ICD-10 criteria
column26: Raymond Irvin does not display clear signs of bipolar disorder with current depressive episode and psychotic symptoms (F31.4). However
column27: his lack of self-confidence
column28: assertiveness issues
column29: dependence in relationships aligning more closely to negative schizophrenia features as per ICD-10's F20.- category on reduced motivation or pleasure could suggest a subthreshold condition but not fitting the specific criteria for Negative Symptoms (F25.8). The information provided does not justify diagnosing Raymond with primary psychotic disorders
column30: and more assessment would be needed to consider such an outcome accurately.

column1: 101§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Richard Balon
column3: a 65-year-old salesman for a large corporation

column1: 102§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Nancy J. Needell

column17: although he said that sometimes when high

column25: he went back to live with his maternal grandmother

It was not clear which substances he was using prior to and during these episodes of psychosis or whether they were implicated in the development of his psychiatric symptoms. column39: but he probably belongs in jail for lots of reasons."§The diagnosis for Vance Orren's case could be Delusional Disorder with a specific subtype of erotomanic type due to his fixed delusions about being persecuted based on sexual orientation. Additionally
column40: there may also be comorbid substance use disorders and past instances suggestive of Wandering in dementia or Bipolar II Disorder symptoms (depressive episode with psychotic features).Note: The provided ICD-10 codes relate to different diagnoses; they do not necessarily apply directly based on the case summary. A thorough mental health evaluation is required for an accurate diagnosis
